conversations.content: Attorney at Caw: Part One
One may laugh at the idiocy of such a thing, but animals frequently used to be put on trial in Alberia.
The defendants—small creatures that destroyed fields, or domestic beasts that injured an owner—were all tried in accordance to human law.
Of course, the animals had no way of understanding what the judge said. Nor could they plead their case; they could only shake their heads and accept the punishment.
One day, a raven was brought to court on a charge of theft, for a ring belonging to the earl's wife had been  found in its nest.
The earl's wife filed the complaint. ＂This filthy raven ripped the ring off my finger as I was walking in our estate gardens!＂ she squawked. ＂Clap him in irons at once!＂
Based on this testimony, the poor raven was arrested and dragged into court. But the dragon Fubuki, who was out on another meandering journey, happened to witness this.
＂A trial, you say?＂ asked Fubuki. ＂Yet as ravens and humans do not speak the same language, it seems I've no choice but to interpret for the poor bird.＂
Everyone in the courtroom was paralyzed with fright. None of them ever thought an animal would seek counsel, let alone that a dragon would rally to its aid.
Thus began a courtroom drama the likes of which the world had never seen—with a clever dragon as its star!
Attorney at Caw: Part Two
Onlookers in the open-air animal court could barely believe their eyes at the sight of a dragon representing a raven—and dressed in human garb, no less!
＂My client claims he found the ring in the forest,＂ said the young dragon, ＂and that he neither stole it nor harmed anyone in the process of obtaining it.＂
＂Additionally, my client claims he saw the earl's wife throw the ring into a bush, which is how he came to be in possession of it.＂
＂What possible reason would the earl's wife have for going to the forest?＂ asked the judge. Oddly, this question caused the woman to turn a deathly shade of white.
Soon the truth emerged: the wife had removed the ring while meeting a lover in the woods. As the raven had taken nothing but what he found on the ground, he was acquitted.
As court adjourned, the chagrined judge asked Fubuki why he chose to  represent the raven in the first place.
＂Human or raven, you're all the same to we dragons,＂ said Fubuki. ＂Do you see? Both of you have two eyes, a nose, and a mouth. You're twins!＂
He went on to say that helping one in need was just the right thing to do, a sentiment agreed to by all.
Wise and well-traveled, Fubuki looked at the world from a very different angle than did humans. He saw the true nature of things.
With the trial concluded, the dragon set off again. Who knows what adventure he will wander into next?
